title: Protocol for in vivo and in vitro activation of NLRP3 inflammasome in mice using monosodium urate
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
MSU activates the NLRP3 inflammasome
Timing: 2 days
NLRP3 inflammasome activation requires two phases: the priming phase and the activation phase. In the priming phase, the inflammatory stimulant LPS activates the NF-κB signaling pathway, which in turn promotes the expression of NLRP3 and pro-IL-1β. In the activation phase, PAMPs and DAMPs induced the assembly of NLRP3 inflammatory vesicles, caspase-1-mediated secretion of IL-1β and IL-18, and pyroptosis. Therefore, LPS priming is an essential step in the activation of NLRP3 inflammasome. MSU is the commonly used DAMPs for classical NLRP3 inflammasome activation This section describes in detail the activation of NLRP3 by MSU and the subsequent detection of relevant indicators.
Seed BMDMs.
Observe the differentiation state of BMDMs under a microscope.
Discard the original culture medium in the culture dish and wash three times with sterile cold PBS.
Note: Rinse with cold sterile PBS to remove other cells that are attached to the bottom of the culture dish.
Prepare a 1% EDTA solution using DMEM medium without FBS and 0.5 M EDTA (pH 8.0) for BMDMs detachment.
Note: Due to the pH change, the DMEM medium turned yellow DMEM medium turns yellow after adding 0.5 M EDTA.
Discard the PBS and treat the cells with 10 mL of 5 mM EDTA for 2 min at room temperature.
Blow off BMDMs with a pipette and collect them in a centrifuge tube.
Centrifuged at 300 × g for 5 min.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend BMDMs with cell culture medium at a density of 5×105/mL.
Culture BMDMs in a 12-well cell culture plate at 1 mL/well and place in a cell culture incubator overnight.
BMDMs primed with LPS.
Preparation of LPS solution: Dissolve LPS powder in ultra-pure water to a concentration of 0.5 mg/mL.

Preparation of LPS medium: Add 1% FBS and 50 ng/mL LPS solution to DMEM medium.
On the second day after seeding, observe the adhesion and morphology of BMDMs under a microscope.
Replace the cell supernatant with 500 μL LPS medium for 4 h of priming.
Critical: The activation of NLRP3 inflammasome requires LPS to initiate the pre-stimulation signal to induce the expression of NLRP3 and Pro-IL-1β, and the effect of LPS is the best at 4 h, so it is recommended to control the LPS stimulation time at 3–6 h.
Add 150 μg/mL MSU to each well for 6 h.
Note: MSU crystals are suspensions and must be mixed before use.
Under the microscope, the BMDMs are partly pyroptotic accompanied by cell swelling and crystals engulfed, and the cells and culture supernatant could be collected.
Collect the cell culture supernatant and centrifuge at 10,000 × g for 5 min, retaining the supernatant for ELISA and western blot.
ELISA: the specific steps of ELISA can be referred to the instructions of mouse IL-1β ELISA kit (R&D system CAS: DY401).
Dilution of ELISA kit: ELISA kits were diluted according to the table of dilution of ELISA kit.
Reagent preparation: PBS, Wash Buffer: PBST (pH 7.2–7.4), Regent Diluent: 1% BSA in PBS, Stop Solution: 1 mol/L H2SO4, Substrate Solution: TMB Substrate Solution.
Critical: Dilution of concentrated sulfuric acid is an exothermic reaction, pay attention to slowly add concentrated sulfuric acid to water when diluting to prevent burns.
Plate coating:
Dilute the Capture Antibody to the working concentration in PBS.
Immediately coat a 96-well microplate with 100 μL per well of the diluted Capture Antibody.
Seal the plate and incubate 12 h at about 25°C.
Aspirate each well and wash with Wash Buffer, repeating the process two times for a total of three washes.

Blocking: Block plates by adding 300 μL of Reagent Diluent to each well. Incubate at about 25°C for 1 h.
Preparation of standards: Take 7 EP tubes, add 1000 μL PBS to tube 1, add 500 μL PBS to the remaining 7 tubes, add reconstituted standard to tube 1 to make the concentration 1000 pg/mL, take 500 μL from tube 1 to tube 2, and then take 500 μL from tube 2 to tube 3, and so on (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Repeat the aspiration/wash as in step d. Add 100 μL of sample or standards per well. Cover with an adhesive strip and incubate 2 h at about 25°C.
Repeat the aspiration/wash as in step d. Add 100 μL of the Detection Antibody, diluted in Reagent Diluent, to each well. Cover with a new adhesive strip and incubate 2 h at about 25°C.
Repeat the aspiration/wash as in step d. Add 100 μL of the working dilution of Streptavidin-HRP to each well. Cover the plate and incubate for 20 min at about 25°C.
Note: Avoid placing the plate in direct light.
Repeat the aspiration/wash as in step d. Add 100 μL of Substrate Solution to each well. Incubate for 20 min at about 25°C.
Note: Avoid placing the plate in direct light.
Add 50 μL of Stop Solution to each well. Gently tap the plate to ensure thorough mixing. Determine the optical density of each well immediately, using a microplate reader set to 450 nm.
Protein extraction.
Supernatant protein extraction:
Add 600 μL of methanol and chloroform mixture (methanol: chloroform = 4: 1), mixed using a vortex apparatus (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).

70 μL of 1.5 × sample buffer was added and the protein was boiled at 100°C for 10 min (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]F).
Cell protein extraction: adherent cells were lysed in 80 μL 1.5 × sample buffer, and the protein was boiled at 100°C for 10 min.
Western blot.
Preparation of SDS-PAGE gels:
Place the glass slide, sample comb, and rubber pad on the gel casting stand. Wash them with detergent and rinse several times with ddH2O, then dry with ethanol.
Put two pieces of washed glass into the gel holder and fix it.
According to the table of SDS-PAGE gel preparation, the components of the separation gel were successively added into the 50 mL centrifuge tube and mixed.
Pour the separation gel between the glass plates, immediately cover with a layer of double steamed water, and the gel can be polymerized after about 30 min.
Note: Sealing water can isolate the air to accelerate the solidification of the gel, moreover, it can make the separation of the gel surface level.
According to the table below, add the concentrated gel components into the 50 mL centrifuge tube in turn and mix well.

Pour the upper double steamed water, pour the concentrated gel, and insert the sample comb.
Note: In every step of gel filling, care should be taken not to pour bubbles into the gel plate, bubbles will seriously affect the final experimental results.
Critical: Many components of SDS-PAGE gel are toxic to humans, so be sure to wear a mask and gloves when preparing and using it.
Electrophoresis:
Assemble the SDS-PAGE gel into the electrophoresis system.
Load the extracted protein samples into the wells.
Run the stacking gel under a constant voltage of 90 V for 30 min.
Run the separating gel under a constant voltage of 120 V for 1 h. Stop the electrophoresis when the molecular weight marker of the target protein is separated.
Membrane transfer:
Cut PVDF membrane of equal size according to the size of the gel and soak the PVDF membrane in methanol for 5 min in advance.
Immerse the items required for membrane transfer in transfer buffer.
Place the membrane clamp with the black side facing down, and then place a sponge and a filter paper in sequence. After electrophoresis, place the gel, activated PVDF membrane, a sponge, and a filter paper in sequence.
Place the rotating membrane clamp in the rotating membrane slot, place it in an ice bag, and rotate for 1 h at voltage of 90 V.
Blocking: Put PVDF membrane into the incubation box with Immunofluorescence block buffer, and slowly shake for 2 h at about 25°C.
Incubation of the primary antibody: Prepare a 1% BSA solution with PBST, and refer to the antibody manual to dilute the primary antibody, and the PVDF membrane was immersed in the primary antibody and shaken 12 h at 4°C.
Incubation of secondary antibody:

Wash the PVDF membrane with PBST for three times, 10 min each time.
Prepare 1% BSA solution with PBST, and refer to the antibody manual to dilute the secondary antibody.
Incubate the PVDF membrane in a secondary antibody containing incubation box at about 25°C for 1 h.
Chemiluminescence imaging:
Discard the secondary antibody, wash the PVDF membrane with PBST for three times, 10 min each time.
Gently press with tissue to absorb the water on the surface of PVDF membrane, apply PVDF membrane to the Western Chemiluminescent HRP Substrate for 2 min, and visualize the membrane in the chemiluminescence imager.
Mice-induced peritonitis
Timing: 12 h
MSU-induced peritonitis is an acute model that can be tested for relevant indicators approximately 6 h after MSU is injected into the peritoneal cavity as described below. Neutrophil recruitment and the level of inflammatory factor IL-1β are markedly increased when peritonitis occurs, so testing the number of neutrophils and the level of IL-1β are preferred in determining the success of peritonitis induction.
Preparation of mice: Purchase male C57/B6 mice at 7 weeks of age and house them in the animal facility for one week to acclimate to the environment.
Administer intraperitoneal injections of 50 mg/kg MSU to the mice, with PBS as the control group.
Note: The MSU suspension must be mixed before intraperitoneal injection, and the injection should be performed quickly and to avoid leakage.
After 6 h, the peritonitis related indicators of mice were detected.
Euthanize the mice with CO2, and open the abdominal wall to fully expose the peritoneum.
Note: The abdominal skin should be open, but the peritoneal cavity must remain intact, this is critical for the success of the lavage.
Inject 500 μL of PBS into the mouse peritoneal cavity using an insulin syringe, and gently massage for 2 min.

Note: Use an insulin syringe to minimize damage to the peritoneal fluid caused by the needle hole.
Collect the ascitic fluid using a 1 mL syringe and centrifuge the supernatants for use in ELISA.
Note: The ELISA procedure is the same as for the detection of IL-1β in cell supernatants.
Wash the mouse peritoneal cavity with 10 mL of PBS containing 1% BSA.
Note: Perform flow cytometry analysis on cells collected from steps 15 and 16 to determine the number of neutrophils.
Reagent preparation: blocking solution: add 0.3 μL CD16/32 to 30 μL PBS. Flow cytometry antibody mixture: add appropriate dilutions of flow antibodies to 30 μL PBS.
Count the collected peritoneal cells, and transfer 1×106 peritoneal cells for flow cytometry analysis.
Block the cells using 30 μL blocking solution at 4°C for 15 min.
Add the mixture of 30 μL flow cytometry antibodies, and incubate in the dark at 4°C for 20 min.
Wash away unbound antibodies using PBS and centrifuged at 300 × g for 3 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant, resuspend the cells, and transferred to flow tube.
Note: Resuspend cells in 300 μL PBS and filter through a 200-mesh nylon mesh into the flow tube.
Use a flow cytometer to detect the number and proportion of neutrophils in the sample, and calculate the total number of neutrophils based on the cell proportion and total number.
Critical: Peritoneal cells should be kept on ice using cold PBS during the experiment.
